conclusion: Need to consider principles of shadow formation and effects of changing light source position.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light source position.
Position of shadow is determined by direction of light rays relative to the object.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the light source positioned above the objects.
When the light source moves forward, the direction of the light rays changes, affecting shadow position and size.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward.
When the light source is closer to the objects, the shadows tend to be larger.
As the light source moves forward, it effectively moves closer to the objects, causing the shadows to become larger.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become larger.
